title: Ticket #2467: getdirentries is broken in stduniv
description:
the getdirentries() system call was discovered to be fragile and broken. Also, the test program was discovered to be broken. Everything relating to this call and the requisite call to getdents() that getdirentries() make, is, in fact, broken.

It appears to have been passing our test suite as a fluke and, in fact, didn't work in standalone mode.
remarks:
2011-Sep-15 14:37:19 by psilord:
I found one problem in that we extract getdirentries from glibc and call it. This call then calls our getdents() call. The problem is that BOTH of them perform the unmapping of the fd through the file table. The second unmap is incorrect and causes failure. It turns out, that it is even worse. We need to unmap the fd when going to the shadow, but not when doing it locally, and there is no means to specify that.

2011-Sep-15 14:38:02 by psilord:
Another problem I found was the test program for getdirentries(). It was simply wrong and worked as a fluke. I have a new test program which fixes this mess.

2011-Sep-19 11:11:12 by psilord:
One major problem, and the reason why getdirentries went red in the first place after my initial commit to fix type correctness in the stub generator, was that when I refactored the stub generator to be type correct for return values of system calls, I missed the handling of the 'code_bytes_bool' expression in the syscall.tmpl file. That expression names the variable symbol in the generated source which holds a length quantity for the coding of a binary array. I had changed some aspects of the stub generator to hold the returned value in a symbol called "ret_val". However, "rval" was a symbol that was still valid in the scope of all of the calls in receivers.cpp. So I ended up choosing the wrong symbol and only wrote a tiny fraction of the bytes in an array back to the job. This fix makes ALL handling of the return valus of system calls use the "ret_val" symbol so it shouldn't happen anymore. I never saw the error from the compiler because it turned out, unluckily, that "rval" and "ret_val" were of the same type in the calls that were failing.

2011-Sep-19 11:22:28 by psilord:
To summarize. The test program for this call actually found an error that I introduced when doing #2337. However, the test and system call emulation were so screwed up, that it took me a while to realize that this happened. Once I fixed the system call and the test, which were both wrong, I discovered the problem with #2337.

2011-Sep-19 14:18:46 by psilord:
Ok, I'm waiting for a green (or green enough, at any rate) test through NMI and then I'll check in my fixes.

2011-Sep-21 10:25:24 by psilord:
Ok, the tests pass. I'm committing this today, but I need to document the bugfix still.

2011-Oct-03 16:41:02 by psilord:
Documented and checked in.
